while the ghosts and spirits on the ground struggled through the gates, competing to come out. The city gates could not accommodate them, and they all rushed out, collapsing the city walls as they went.
At that time, all the impurities, filth, and foul odors in the city sank into the ground, and the high and low places became level.
The blind could see, the deaf could hear, the mute could speak, and the crippled could walk. The insane regained their senses, and the sick were cured.
Elephants, horses, cows, and other animals cried out in harmony, and stringed instruments such as the pipa sounded by themselves, with the notes in perfect harmony.
The women's jewelry jingled with a wonderful sound, and vessels and jars made a natural sound, soft and harmonious, with the wonderful sound of the Dharma.
Treasures buried underground naturally emerged.
All sentient beings were like those who had suffered from heat and thirst, obtaining cool water to drink and bathe in, feeling refreshed and relieved;
The entire city's illnesses were cured and liberated, just like this.

The Buddha and the great assembly then left the city. Out of great compassion, wishing to bestow great protection upon sentient beings, they circumambulated the city, making wishes at each gate, expounding the wonderful Dharma to remove misfortune and bring blessings. The country's illnesses and epidemics were all eliminated, and the entire realm became peaceful.
Then, Caiming bowed at the Buddha's feet, knelt for a long time with palms joined, and said to the World-Honored One:

Previously you showed compassion and agreed. I only wish that tomorrow, together with the great assembly, you will out of pity for sentient beings, turn your light and look upon me, coming to my house for a vegetarian meal.
The Buddha silently accepted.
He joyfully leapt up, circumambulated to the right three times, bowed to the Buddha, and withdrew.
He returned home to prepare a hundred flavors of food and drink, pure and fragrant, with fresh colors and delicious tastes;
He decorated his house, hung silk banners and canopies, set up beds and cushions, sprinkled the ground with fragrant water, and scattered flowers and burned incense.
When the offerings were prepared, he knelt for a long time at the gate, burned incense, and spoke to the Buddha from afar, saying:
Please come down in due course.
At that time, the World-Honored One instructed his disciples to put on their robes and take their bowls, and went to the elder Caiming to receive the invitation.
They arrived at the gate, and Caiming respectfully invited the Buddha into the house with flowers, incense, and music. The Buddha and the noble assembly took their seats in order.
At that time, Caiming held a golden vase and personally served water, pouring it himself, equally high and low.
After the meal was finished, he again served water, knelt for a long time with his hands clasped, and said to the Buddha:
I only wish that the World-Honored One would extend the mind of the four equalities and accept the invitation for three more days as he does now.
The Buddha silently assented.
Then, Caiming offered to the Buddha and the noble assembly various fragrant and clean [food], just like the first day.
After four days, he offered golden cloth worth 100,000 to the highest seat, cloth worth 90,000 to the next seat, and so on, down to cloth worth 10,000 to the lowest seat, as a donation.
His wife then rose, knelt for a long time with her hands clasped, and said to the World-Honored One:
Only, Heavenly Honored One!
Compassionately extend to humans and things, please stay your divine light and accept this lowly concubine's invitation to stay for another four days.
The Buddha silently accepted.
His wife made offerings, on the first day, the second day, up to the fourth day, with fragrant and clean food, no different.
After four days, he again offered golden cloth worth 100,000 to the World-Honored One, cloth worth 90,000 to the next, and the lowest worth 10,000.
At that time, Caiming's son rose to the Buddha's front, knelt for a long time with his hands clasped, and said to the World-Honored One:
Only, Heavenly Honored One!
We have already received four days of food from our parents. Please, out of compassion and pity, accept our four days of invitations.
The Buddha also silently accepted.

His son diligently made offerings for four days, with delicious food just like his parents. He then offered the World-Honored One a golden robe worth 100,000, a middle seat worth 90,000, and a lower seat worth 10,000.
The son's wife also rose and knelt for a long time, saying to the Buddha:
World-Honored One, your great compassion!
You have already accepted the offerings from my mother-in-law, father-in-law, and husband. Please, as before, accept our four days.
The Buddha again silently accepted.
The food and drink prepared were no different from before, also lasting four days. She also offered a golden robe worth 100,000, a middle seat worth 90,000, and a lower seat worth 10,000 as a gift.

The entire family, young and old, sat in front of the Buddha and received his teachings. What merits and virtues does the elder Caiming have?

He invited the Buddha and the great assembly for sixteen days, and the king, ministers, and people made offerings and gifts, reaching every corner of the country, and all were able to enjoy the sweet dew.
Is it from merit in past lives?

I only pray that the World-Honored One will explain his past conduct, resolving all doubts!
The Buddha told Ä€nanda and the great assembly,

At that time, there was a pratyekabuddha staying in the mountains. He got up early, washed his face, put on his Dharma robes, took his alms bowl, and left the mountain to seek food. Before reaching the village, he encountered a violent storm.
Not far from the road, there was an official orchard with a caretaker.
He saw smoke coming out and went to inform the master:ğŸ”½'While traveling, I encountered a storm. Please allow me to enter the house, warm myself by the fire, and dry my robes.'
He invited him in, took firewood to start a fire, and helped him dry his robes.
The robes were dry and his body warm.
When the storm subsided a little, he put on his robes and was about to leave.
The orchard caretaker asked:
'Virtuous one!
Where are you going?'
He replied:
'Wise one!
All beings who have form depend on clothing and food for life.
I have left home to study, and I sustain myself by begging for food;
If I do not get food, my life and body will not be sustained, and my faculties will be unstable, unable to contemplate the Way.'
The park keeper replied:
'My poor family's vegetarian food is coarse in color and sour in taste. If you are willing to accept it, please stay and do not leave.
' The pratyekabuddha replied:
'When studying the Way and seeking food, I do not care about color or taste. I just need to fill my body.
If you agree to give me food, I will stay and not leave.'
Then the park keeper went home to get rice.
When he got home, he asked his wife:
'Is the meal ready?'
She replied:
'It is ready.'
In that country, the food was served separately.
The husband said to his wife:
'Bring my share, as I have an important guest I want to feed.'
The wife then thought to herself:
'Since the husband is a man, he should take on the hard work and endure the cold and heat. Even if he doesn't eat, he can't do the hard work.
I am a woman, staying at home leisurely. You can take my share and use it to entertain the guest.'
The son said again:
'My parents are old, so they can eat by themselves. I will give my share to you.'
The son's wife said:
'My mother-in-law and husband have agreed to feed the guest. I am young and strong, able to endure hunger and thirst. Please take my share and use it to feed the guest.'
The adults then said:
'You all have good intentions to give. We can reduce our own shares and have enough to feed the guest.'
So they each reduced their own rice shares.
The park keeper thought again:
'The Daoist's clothes are torn and his body is exposed.'
He asked his wife:
'Do we have any spare clothes at home?'
His wife replied:
'At home, we only have one set of linen clothes. We will share them when we receive guests. There is nothing else.'
The husband said to his wife:
'In previous lives, I did not give any alms, and now I am poor and lowly, not equal to others.
If I do not give now, when will I ever escape poverty and lowliness?
Those who are wealthy, noble, and have food and clothing naturally are all due to the blessings of giving alms in previous lives.
Now, if I continue to give alms, I will never be satisfied.
I also do not need to change my clothes to attend guests at the door.'
Taking the folded cloth and food, the whole family went to the practitioner's place, washed their hands, and offered the food.
After the practitioner finished eating, washed his mouth, and cleaned his bowl, the four people offered the folded cloth to the pratyekabuddha, who then put it on.
The pratyekabuddha did not teach the Dharma, but manifested spiritual powers to delight sentient beings and make them give rise to the intention for enlightenment. He said to the host,
'You are able to give alms and make offerings to the practitioner. Firmly strengthen your resolve and make a great vow.
Having spoken, he ascended into the sky, sat in the lotus position, and remained standing and walking, manifesting as pratyekabuddhas, filling the sky.
Each manifested transformations, emitting water and fire from their bodies, with the water not extinguishing the fire and the fire not encroaching on the water, with various transformations.
Flying through the sky, they returned to the mountain where the immortals lived.
The garden supervisor and his retinue rejoiced, with palms joined in respect, they kowtowed and begged for mercy, then made this vow:
By the merit and virtue of today's offering to the sagely and enlightened spiritual practitioner, may we be free from the three evil destinies of hell, hungry ghosts, and animals;

Wherever we are born, may we always gather together in the heavens and the human realm, with abundant wealth and peace, with the power of enlightened wisdom, and may we savor the taste of immortality like the sagely and enlightened teacher;
If we encounter a sagely teacher, may we have extraordinary spiritual virtues.
The Buddha said to the assembly:
The garden supervisor at that time was Cai Ming.
His wife, son, and daughter-in-law were all the same person.

Since then, for ninety-one kalpas, they did not fall into the three evil paths again, but received vast blessings and rewards, and in the heavens and the human realm, the family members gathered together and did not part from each other.

At that time, they made a vow, wishing to drink the sweet dew, attain enlightenment, and encounter an excellent teacher. For this reason, they now encountered me, met with the supreme enlightenment, which is immeasurable and incomparable, and now drink the sweet dew, just like their former teacher.

At that time, the great assembly, hearing the Buddha proclaim the rewards and retributions of merits and virtues, was delighted and joyful, their minds and thoughts clear. They took refuge in the Three Jewels of the Buddha, Dharma, and the Sagely Assembly. Their knots were unraveled, and some received the five precepts, while others left the household life to study.

At that time, in the assembly, four thousand people all attained the fruits of the path of the stream-enterer, once-returner, non-returner, and arhat, and countless people gave rise to the intention of the Great Vehicle, their minds not turning back.
Then, the World-Honored One rose and left the house, and the entire great assembly bowed and each departed.

The Buddha saw that she was sent by MÄra to destroy the purity of precepts, concentration, wisdom, liberation, and the knowledge and insight of liberation. He then spoke to the monks with a BrahmÄ voice:

You should contemplate the things that women possess, deceiving everyone like gold-plated coins. The thin skin is like a fly's wing, covering the filth. Bones and flesh are connected, a mass of blood and flesh. Eyes are filled with tears and saliva. The body sweats and is dirty. If not washed and wiped:
Think like this, contemplate the body of a woman, and restrain the deluded thoughts of lust.

Contemplate the skeleton, bound with sinews, smeared with blood and flesh, covered with clothes, adorned with flowers and colors, like a painter standing on a wall, smearing the filth with mud, and painting with colored powders. The body of a woman is also like this. You should contemplate and know this, eliminating lustful thoughts.
If one wishes to study the Way, first regulate the mind, and then one can attain peace. If one does not first regulate the mind, it will be too late to regret later.
Erroneous conduct and delusion are like a donkey, facing the end of its life, wishing to go against its intentions, and will never be liberated.
Those who view form and have a deluded mind, consider impermanence to be permanence, suffering to be happiness, non-self to be self, and impurity to be purity;
Wisdom realizes impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and impurity. One who understands this will be free from the long journey of birth and death and its difficulties.
The Buddha taught this to the disciples, and they all accepted and upheld it, wholeheartedly practicing it.

When Naivedya saw the Buddha, like the sun emerging from the clouds, with golden light illuminating, she gave rise to a pure mind, prostrated with her whole body, bowed at the Buddha's feet, and sat to one side.
The Buddha told Naivedya:
Women are emotionally unrestrained and deluded by the five desires.
You are able to control your mind, bow to the Buddha, enjoy the wonderful Dharma, and be transformed. This is your greatest benefit.
Men are at ease and have thin defilements. Enjoying the Dharma and being transformed is not considered strange;
Women are entangled in the net of defilements and afflictions, spinning around and obstructed, not knowing the way out.
All worlds are suffering, empty, impermanent, and unreliable. Strength and vigor invade youth, old age robs one's complexion, and death seizes one's life. Danger invades safety.
In order to leave these afflictions, one should single-mindedly accept the Dharma, diligently cultivate and practice it, and thereby avoid this suffering.
Women's hatred and resentment are extremely evil when they meet, and their affection and love are also very much missed when they part.
In general, women are never far from these two things.

Therefore, women should diligently uphold the Dharma, so as to avoid the gathering of resentment and the separation of affection and love. They will no longer encounter birth, old age, sickness, and death, and all suffering will completely cease.
When Na-chuang heard the Buddha's various wonderful teachings about the impurity of women, she felt ashamed and immediately stood up, knelt for a long time, joined her palms, and said to the Buddha,
Please have compassion and come to my house with the saá¹…gha to receive food.
The Buddha then silently accepted.

After the meal, the Buddha spoke extensively about the blessings and rewards of giving, the fruits of being cautious, the happiness of heavenly beings and humans, which cannot last long, the danger of separation and loss, which cannot be relied upon, only the four noble truths and the eightfold noble path, which bring great peace and forever eliminate worries and troubles.
Their minds were all joyful, doubts were removed, bonds were unraveled, and they attained the stage of stream-entry.
The assembly sat with doubts:
What merit did the girl in the fig tree have in her past life, that she was born from a tree, upright and beautiful?
The Venerable Ä€nanda, knowing the assembly's doubts, knelt with palms joined and said to the Buddha:

The assembly is all doubtful. In what field of merit did the girl in the fig tree plant roots of virtue in her past life, that she now encounters the World-Honored One and takes the sweet dew medicine?
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
In the past, during the time of KÄÅ›yapa Buddha, when the human lifespan was twenty thousand years, the Buddha's work was completed and he again relinquished his life.

She removed the impurities with her hand, then washed her hands and circumambulated the stupa, making a wish:

The women who swept the stupa grounds at that time are the women in this assembly now.

At that time, in sweeping the grounds and wishing to extinguish the afflictions, they imbibed the taste of the sweet dew. The woman who removed the dog feces with her hand at that time is now the woman named Na.

At that time, she made a vow not to associate with defilements, and to be born in purity. By this meritorious reward, she did not take birth through the foul and stinking womb, but was always born from a flower.
Because at that time she uttered one evil sound, calling her a prostitute, she now receives the name of a prostitute.

The Buddha extensively explained the retributions of good and evil, the glory and joy of the heavens and the world, and the suffering of the three evil paths, devouring each other, and crying out in distress.

At that time, the assembly heard what the Buddha said, took refuge in the Three Jewels of the Buddha, Dharma, and the Holy Sangha, eliminated the actions of body, speech, and mind, and practiced the ten wholesome deeds;
countless people each established the intention for enlightenment in the Three Vehicles.

Then, the World-Honored One returned to the monastery.
